Dear Mack McGhee:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer, at 517-899-6024.
Sincerely,
Vivian Malleck, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 09/24/2024, a youth ingested a battery and metal clips at the
facility. Youth has been brought to the hospital 11 times between
July and present due to ingestion of items. Youth has 2:1 staffing
and supervision concerns continue.
Investigation Interviews
Messages were left for Complainant on 09/27/2024 and
10/11/2024. Complainant returned call on 10/14/2024. Returned
call and left a message for Complainant on 10/14/2024.
Complainant has not returned call.
Youth A was interviewed on 09/26/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention with another DHHS worker. Youth A stated he
climbed on a Charles Inniss unit desk, broke the smoke detector
on the ceiling, pulled out the battery and ate the battery. Youth A
stated staff (did not identify) tried to get him off the desk and
directed him not to swallow the battery. Youth A stated he
ingested the battery and was sent to the hospital. Youth A stated
he was told the battery would naturally pass through his digestive
system. Youth A denied discomfort or pain. A tour of Charles
Inniss unit was done on 09/26/2024. Youth A stated he is six feet
and one inch in height. It would be impossible for Youth A to reach
the ceiling standing on the fixed and secured metal ledge or metal
table on the unit due to the height of the ceiling.
Youth B was interviewed on 11/06/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention. Youth B stated maintenance broke the
television remote on Charles Inniss unit and discarded the broken
remote in the unit’s garbage can. Youth B stated Youth A took a
battery (either AA or AAA battery) out of the broken remote and
ate it. Youth B stated Youth A ate the battery because he was
upset that a certain staff was not on the unit. Youth B stated Staff
2

3 tried to redirect and remove the battery from Youth A's mouth,
but Youth A refused to spit it out. Youth B stated a nurse came to
the unit and sent Youth A to the hospital.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 10/02/2024 at Wayne County Juvenile
Detention. Staff 1 stated Youth A said he was “trying to beat the
system” by ingesting objects to prevent residential placement.
Staff 1 stated Youth A believed his behaviors would result in an
emergency court hearing that would result in him returning directly
home. Staff 1 stated Youth A stood on a desk on Unit 1B and tried
to break the ceiling tiles. Staff 1 stated he redirected Youth A's
thinking errors and asked for Youth A to get down. Staff 1 stated
Youth A stepped down from the desk with his assistance and did
not ingest pieces of ceiling tile or a battery in this incident. Staff 1
stated there was another incident when Youth A pulled apart the
computer monitor on the staff desk and may have ingested screws
and some type of metal clip. Staff 1 stated Youth A is not
compliant with redirection given his belief that he will return home
when he acts out. Staff 1 stated nursing assesses Youth A after
each possible incident of him ingesting a foreign object.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 10/10/2024 at Wayne County Juvenile
Detention with another DHHS worker. Staff 2 stated Youth A stood
on a desk and tried to break the ceiling tiles on Unit 1B and not on
Charles Inniss unit. Staff 2 stated Youth B was not successful and
did not ingest any piece of a ceiling tile. Staff 2 stated Youth A
complied with his directive to step down from the desk and
apologized for his behavior. Staff 2 stated he is unaware of Youth
A ingesting a battery.
Staff 3 was interviewed on 10/17/2024 by phone because she is
no longer employed at Wayne County Juvenile Detention. Staff 3
stated Nurse told Youth A that she would come back to speak with
him on Charles Inniss unit. Staff 3 stated Youth A became
agitated and pulled something out of the trash can and told her
that he was going to swallow a battery. Staff 3 stated she was
confused by Youth A’s comment because she did not believe he
had a battery or had access to a battery. Staff 3 stated Youth A
slid under the shower door (shower door is not flush with the floor)
and exited when she unlocked the shower door. Staff 3 stated she
secured from Youth A a television remote and a small wire spring,
which was possibly from the television remote. Staff 3 stated she
then tried to physically open Youth A’s mouth with her hands
when he made chewing motions. Staff 3 stated she saw black
residue in Youth A’s mouth and placed her fingers inside Youth
A’s mouth to encourage him to spit out the battery. Staff 3 stated
3

she called for assistance when the battery was not retrieved. Staff
3 stated Nurse came to the unit and tried the Heimlich on Youth A.
Staff 3 stated Youth A fell to the floor upset when Nurse left the
unit but got up with redirection. Staff 3 stated additional staff came
to the unit and escorted Youth A off the unit to the hospital for an
evaluation. Staff 3 stated Youth A did not have trouble breathing
and was able to speak throughout this incident. Staff 3 stated
Youth A told her at one point in the incident that he saw
maintenance workers (employed by Wayne County and not
Wayne County Juvenile Detention) drop and break the television
remote and throw the remote in the garbage can. Staff 3 stated
Youth B witnessed this incident and Supervisor 1 responded to
the assistance call.
Therapist was interviewed on 10/30/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention with her social work intern and another DHHS
worker. Therapist stated she responded to an assistance call
about Youth A chewing and swallowing a battery. Therapist stated
she did not know how Youth A obtained the battery, but she tried
to redirect Youth A to spit the battery out. Therapist stated Youth
A said he “needed to get out” and to go to the hospital. Therapist
stated she meets frequently with Youth A for crisis intervention
because he pushes limits and ingests foreign objects. Therapist
stated Youth A believes his acting out behaviors will prompt a
transfer to another unit or to the hospital. Therapist stated Youth A
shared that the hospital food is better and the bed is more
comfortable then at Wayne County Juvenile Detention.
Nurse was interviewed on 10/31/2024 by phone. Nurse stated she
responded to an assistance call about Youth A chewing on a
battery. Nurse stated Youth A did not tell her how he obtained the
battery, but told her that he swallowed it. Nurse stated she called
poison control, contacted the doctor and Youth A was sent to the
emergency room for an evaluation.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 11/06/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention with another DHHS worker. Supervisor 1
stated Youth A often ingests foreign objects. Supervisor 1 does
not recall the specifics of Youth A ingesting a battery on Charles
Inniss unit.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 10/10/2024 at Wayne County
Juvenile Detention with another DHHS worker. Supervisor 2 does
not recall an incident when Youth A ingested a battery, but stated
Youth A often ingests foreign objects. Supervisor 2 stated Youth A
4

has been on a one staff to one youth ratio for approximately a
month to assist with his propensity to ingest foreign objects.
Video
This is a summary of main events from the Charles Inniss unit
09/24/2024 video footage from 3:55 PM to 4:40 PM. One female
staff is on the unit with Youth A and Youth B. Youth A slides under
a shower door. Staff opens the shower door and Youth A exits.
Youth A walks around and reaches into a garbage can. Staff
follows Youth A and swipes at his hand twice when his hand
moves towards his mouth. Youth A steps onto the couch and Staff
also steps onto the couch. Staff places her hand on Youth A’s
cheeks and squeezes inwards. Youth A gives something to Staff
when they step off the couch. Staff walks to the unit’s main door
and slides something under the door. Additional staff (supervisors)
arrive on the unit and walk to Youth A standing by the garbage
can. Nursing staff arrive on the unit and speak with Youth A.
Youth A tilts his head back and tries to swallow something. A
nurse follows and talks with Youth A before attempting a Heimlich
like thrust. Nurse continues to hold Youth A from behind as the
female staff places her pointer finger inside of Youth A’s mouth.
Youth A and female staff appear to laugh. The additional staff
leave the unit. Youth A walks around and slides in and out under
the shower door. Youth A walks around and falls to the ground.
Female staff hover over Youth A and check on him. Youth A gets
up and goes to the garbage can. Youth A walks around, falls to
the ground and hits his head on the back of the wall. Youth A gets
up without issue when additional staff arrive. Youth A exits the unit
with staff. During this incident Youth B walks around and stands to
the side watching Youth A.
Documentation
Staff 3 wrote an incident report about Youth A ingesting a battery
on 09/24/2024 on Charles Inniss unit. The following was not
stated in Staff 3’s interview but was written in the incident report.
• Staff 3 opened the shower room door. Youth A exited and
opened his mouth revealing a battery and a piece of glass.
• Youth A gave the glass piece to Staff 3 but refused to spit
out the battery. Staff 3 slid the glass piece under the door
to Supervisor.
• Youth A placed another battery in his mouth when he slid
out of the shower room the second time.
• Youth A placed a long, sharp object in his mouth. Before he
was escorted off the unit.
5

Youth A’s 09/2024 nursing progress notes were reviewed. Youth
A was evaluated by Wayne County Juvenile Detention nursing
staff for ingesting foreign objects on 09/01/2024, 09/02/2024,
09/03/2024, 09/04/2024, 09/07/2024, 09/09/2024, 09/15/2024,
and 09/24/2024. Each incident resulted in Youth A going to the
hospital.
Tour
Upon entering Charles Inniss unit to the left are two youth rooms
and then two showering rooms. Upon entering Charles Inniss unit
to the right is a small, counter height, rectangular ledge secured to
the middle of the wall. Next to this ledge is a small metal table with
two stools, each secured to the ground. This unit also has two
individual couches, a wall mounted television and a large garbage
can.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance because staff redirect, and
nursing staff assess Youth A when he is intent on ingesting
foreign objects. Please see the next section in this report, Rule
400.4127 (3) Staff to resident ratio, regarding Youth A’s
supervision needs.
CONSULATION
Educate maintenance staff about the population in care and
precautions required (e.g. tools on a unit, disposing items) to
ensure a safe and secure environment.
Remind staff that it is not best practice to place fingers in a youth’s
mouth to retrieve or expel a foreign object in the mouth. This
action may result in fingers being bit or pushing the foreign object
further down the throat.
Consideration for suicide gown to be part of a youth’s behavior
plan when the youth is active in harboring contraband to ingest.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
6

Rule Code Staff to resident ratio.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (3) The ratio formula for direct care workers shall correspond with
Description the institution’s purpose and the needs of the residents and shall
assure the continual safety, protection and direct care and
supervision of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Additional Finding
Investigation Interview
Staff 3 was interviewed on 10/17/2024 by phone because she is
no longer employed at Wayne County Juvenile Detention. Staff 3
stated she was assigned to Youth A on 09/24/2024 as his one
staff to one youth ratio, but she worked the shift by herself with
Youth A and Youth B on Charles Inniss unit.
Video
09/24/2024 Charles Inniss unit video review shows Staff 3 was on
the unit by herself with Youth A and Youth B until she called for
assistance.
Documentation
Wayne County Juvenile Detention compiled a list of Youth A’s
assigned staff for his one staff to one youth ratio from 08/27/2024
to 10/01/2024 for 7:00 AM to 3:00 PM and 3:00 PM to 11:00 PM
shifts. It states Staff 3 is assigned to Youth A on 09/24/2024 from
3:00 PM to 11:00 PM for his one staff to one youth ratio.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance in providing Youth A his
one staff to one youth ratio status. The video footage supports
Staff 3’s interview that she was on Charles Inniss unit by herself
on 09/24/2024 with Youth A and Youth B.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

Rule Code Program statement.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans and discharge of
residents.
Violation Additional Finding
Type
Investigation Documentation
Staff 3 wrote an incident report on 09/26/2024 for the 09/24/2024
incident about Youth A securing a battery on Charles Inniss unit
and ingesting it.
Wayne County Juvenile Detention Incident Report Rationale
policy and procedure 6.1 states incident reports are to be entered
in the system before the end of the shift that the incident occurred.
It also states a supervisor ensures the incident report is written
and entered into the system.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance because Staff 1 wrote the
incident report on 09/26/2024 and not on 09/24/2024 when the
incident occurred.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

As a result of the findings in this investigation, a corrective action plan is required.

sir_summary.summary: A special investigation found that a youth with a documented history of ingesting objects was able to access and swallow a battery from a broken remote control discarded in a garbage can. The facility was found in non-compliance for failing to provide a mandated 1:1 staff ratio for the youth at the time of the incident, and for a repeat violation of not filing an incident report by the end of the shift. While staff attempted redirection, the failure to maintain the required supervision ratio directly contributed to the incident, indicating facility culpability.
